Narissa has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Narissa joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narissa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela T. is from the village of Banawan, Iligan City. She is 50 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Adela owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling bananas in the local community. Adela has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Adela joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adela is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella S. is from the city of Katipunan. She is 55 years old, married and has eight adult-aged children. To make a living, Estrella owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns on average 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2006, Estrella joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her ninth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
C., 28, (who was not available for photographing) is a long-term business woman. She is married and has given birth to three school-aged children. Her husband is shown in the photograph.

Before C. had children, she used to sell a few cooking supplies from her home. In the past, she used her little capital to build a mall store, which is where she now sells her items. She currently relies on part of her husband’s income from his work as an electrician.

C. hopes to improve and enlarge on her investment by using a Kiva loan to accumulate a quantity of grocery inventory to resell for additional profits.

loans.use: To accumulate a quantity of grocery inventory to resell.

loans.name: Joven

texts.en:
Joven is a resident of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. Due to financial difficulties, he was not able to pursue his college education. He is now married to Rovelyn and they are blessed with a child, Jolin, who is 12 years old and already in high school. They have a great dream for their child so they are striving hard to provide for her needs and to save for her future. 

Joven’s wife is working as an Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW) in Dubai while Joven is engaged in a vegetable planting and vending business.  Joven plants different varieties of vegetables, such as eggplant, beans, bitter melon, and tomatoes. With his diligence, he is able to earn enough income to meet their daily needs and to support the education of their child. With his desire to increase his income and not to depend too much on the salary of his wife abroad, he has decided take a loan of PHP5,000. He is hoping that the lenders will assist him so he can expand his small business.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is 45 years old. She is managing a general store business along the street of Santiago City. Aside from her store, she is also selling second hand or used Ready to Wear Clothes (RTW) to generate extra income for her family. At present, Angela wants to borrow a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5,000 to use as business capital. Through this amount, she believes that her resulting income will increase.  

Angela serves as mother and father to her son, John Paul, 21 years old.  He has just graduated from college and is looking for a job. She is thankful because, through her patience in maintaining her business, she has been able to support the education of her son.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is married to Oscar. They live harmoniously with their four children in the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. They are striving hard to earn a living in order to support the education of their children. Their primary source of income is farming and they help each other in planting a variety of vegetables. 

Margarita is a fruit and vegetable vendor in the market and in their village.  Sometimes she roams around their village to sell her products, but most of the time she stays at her stall in the market. She now wants to request a loan amounting to PHP5,000 from KIVA loans. This will help towards the growth of her vending business. She hopes to strengthen her business so that she can meet the needs of their children. She hopes that her business will grow and the children will finish their studies.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea C., 49, is homemaker. She stays at home to care for her two children, and holds a daily routine as well. Her husband provides for the family’s expenses with his income as a domestic statue carver. He buys a piece of wood and then carves it into formal statues. He also sells his finished items to people who need to decorate and charm their house. Recently, he ran out of raw material from his stock supply. This has caused frequent interruption to his operations. Therefore, Chea C. would like a loan of US$700 to be used to buy wood and some carving tools for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy wood and some carving tools for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Fernando Jr.

texts.en:
Fernando makes and sells stoves made from clay and cement.  He lives in Barangay Marasat, Paqueńo in San Mateo, Isabela with his family. He is proud of his business, though it is small, for it is a decent one and it really helps his family.  His wife, Lydia, is very supportive and helpful in his business while their two children serve as his inspiration. Their children are: June Vear – 7 years old and Neslyn – 5 years old. Both children are in the elementary level at school. 

Fernando wants his business to grow and be known to other villages so that he can sell more stoves and gain a bigger income.  In order for him to attain it, he needs additional capital and he is now asking for a loan of PHP 8,000.00 from the KIVA lenders.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Yet

texts.en: Yet S. is a widower, aged 42. He is a father blessed with two teenaged children who are going to school. He is currently a local teacher for a public school. Yet S. finds it hard commuting to work or anywhere else, because he doesn’t have his own vehicle for his traveling needs. Therefore, he requests a loan to add to his savings to buy a used motor which he will use to ride to school for his teaching job.

loans.use: To buy a used motor which he will use to ride to school for his teaching job.

loans.name: Qadseya Group

texts.en:
Qadseya is the group leader of Qadseya group. There are four members in this group. All of them want to borrow money for their businesses.

Rona and Qadseya want to take out a loan for their tailoring business because they want to buy a new sewing machine.

Masoda needs a loan so that her husband can buy necessary materials for his business of selling fruit from his cart.

Bibi Monesa would like to enable her husband to buy what he needs for his business as a mechanic.

They are requesting a loan in the amount of 40,000 Afghani. With this loan they can make their businesses larger, support their families, and make a better future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: To improve their businesses

loans.name: Kin

texts.en: C. is a 25-year-old farmer who lives in Pursat Province. C. is married to Mr. Sin, age 27, who works with her in the farming business (they appear in the picture). This couple has been planning a rice crop (two months ago) but their crop is not growing; thus, they have decided to seek a loan to purchase fertilizer in order to fatten their crop yield.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer in order to fatten their rice crop yield.

loans.name: Kean

texts.en: Kean I, 40, lives in the province of Pursat, Cambodia, where she owns and works a plot of land next to her house, growing both rice and vegetables. She can plant her crops twice a year, a trade she was taught by her grandfather. She is currently good mother to her three teenaged children. The first child helps her on the farm, the second child is a fisherman, while the last one attends school. She is married to Choeun Chin, age 41, a domestic fisherman and rice farmer. Kean I will be using her loan to pay for the cost of plowing her farmland and to buy fertilizer for her crop yield. She and her husband are shown in the picture at their field.

loans.use: To pay the cost of plowing her farmland and to buy fertilizer for her crop.

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Tep N., 47, owns a small grocery store next to her house where she sells cooking supplies for her neighbors in the village. She usually buys produce in bulk from a marker supplier to resell in order to gain income. She is a widowed mother who has given birth to two teenage children; two of whom are employed. Tep’s first daughter is a garment worker, while the last one works for a hotel. both daughters provide their income to meet their family's financial crisis. Tep N. applies for a loan to purchase a larger amount of cooking items to continue selling.

loans.use: to purchase a larger amount of cooking items to sell.

loans.name: Razia Group

texts.en:
This is the Esani group. The group is made up of two members. Razia is the group leader. Both of the group members would like to take out a loan to help the businesses progress, and for buying essential materials.

Razia would like to take out a loan for her husband who has a car parts shop. He needs to purchase the required equipment for his business.

Liala wants to take out a loan for her brother’s vegetable shop so that he can expand his business. They have requested a group loan of 28000 Afghani. They are happy that this loan process exists for the support of all the entrepreneurs around the world.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials

loans.name: Raymund

texts.en:
Raymund D. is from the village of Banawan, Iligan city. He is 29 years old. Raymund is single. To make a living, Raymund owns & operates a service-based business. Raymund is just starting this taxi services business.

In 2009, Raymund joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to engage in business activities. Raymund is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Raymund from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide taxi services.

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is a member of the Amani west borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 25 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 7, 5, 3 years old.

Jesca has owned a business selling oil, salts, for 1 year. She works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 70,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Jesca`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 TSh in order to buy more commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Jesca hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for  sale

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie C. is from the village of Banawan, Iligan City. She is 47 years old. Elsie is married and has 3 adult children. Elsie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. She sells both food & daily use products in the local community. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elsie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth  is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 25 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 10, 6, 3 years old.

Janeth has owned a grocery business for 2 years, she works 15 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 120,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Janeth`s first loan from BRC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more drinks for her grocery.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of loan, Janeth hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more drinks fro Grocery business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia M. is from the village of  Banawan, Iligan City. She is 48 years old. Virginia is married and has 6 adult children. Virginia owns & operates a business raising pigs for resale. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Vasyl

texts.en:
Vasyl runs a transportation services business in his hometown of Ivano-Frankivsk and the region. He is married. His transportation services are always in demand, which helps Vasyl make good money and run his business efficiently. Vasyl has been in this trade for 5 years. Presently, he earns about 5,000 Grivnyas of monthly income.

He seeks a loan of 7,000 Grivnyas to do major repairs to his vehicle’s engine. He is hoping to continue running this business as it brings good income for him and for his family. Vasyl is an experienced technician and knows a lot about vehicles. He used to sell cars in the local car market but decided to quit to launch his own small venture. Vasyl is happy to have this business as it feeds his family and helps him to survive in this challenging economic environment.

loans.use: Major repairs of the vehicle engine.

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila, married, runs a small business selling jewelry items in the local mall in her hometown of Vasilyevka. Her merchandise is always very elegant and her prices are competitive. Ludmila has kept her business running for the past 5 years due to her outstanding determination and stamina. Currently, she earns about 70,000 Grivnyas of gross income a month.

Ludmila is seeking a loan of 12,000 Grivnyas in order to increase her working capital. Many of her customers are investing their funds in gold items in this unstable time of global economic recession. Ludmila is an optimist. She always hopes for the best and believes that her business will continue to grow and to provide a good income in the future as well.

loans.use: to increase her working capital.

loans.name: Nadya Group

texts.en: Nadya is the group leader of Nadya group. There are four members in this group. They requested a group loan of 56,000 Afghani. Nadya wants to take a loan for their tailoring business. And Rahema wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of running a general store. Also Sajeda wants to take a loan for her brother’s video shop. Bahdar K. wants to take a loan for his business. They want to expand and promote their business.

loans.use: Expand and promote their business

loans.name: Jowali's Group

texts.en: M. Jowali is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is a hard working and responsible man. M. is married and has 5 children, the eldest being in Senior 1. His family also cares for 2 orphans. Jowali is a driver in Mukono. He has had a taxi business, which he operates on the Mukono – Kampala route, for 13 years and he is happy that at least he is able to earn 100,000 UGX a week. He is mostly challenged with the occasional problem of mechanical failure. However, the loans plus a little savings helps him in sorting this out. He knows how to treat his customers well and this has enabled him to win their trust. He needs a loan to help pay for his children’s school fees and to repair his taxi.

loans.use: Towards children's school fees and for repairing his taxi.

loans.name: Marylovelyn

texts.en:
Marylovelyn P., 19-year-old single mother of two infant-aged children from the village of Cabaksahan, Iligan City, owns and operates a specialized retail store whose main source of income comes from selling bananas in the local community. Marylovelyn is just starting this business.

In 2009, Marylovelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Charles' Group

texts.en:
Charles N. is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. A friendly and hard-working man, he has operated a fish-selling business from Mukono for four years now. He gets his fish from many sites in and around Mukono, based on where the prices are most favorable, thus enabling him to make some profits out of his transactions. He is requesting a loan to buy more fish for resale. His goal is to open an additional stall to sell from so he earn more in order to pay for his children’s school fees with ease.

Charles is married with five children, the eldest six years old and in primary one; he also takes care of three grandparents.

loans.use: Buying more fish for resale.

loans.name: Tuoi

texts.en: Tươi Thị Đinh, born in 1970, lives in Xom Chợ, Uy Nỗ, Đông Anh, Hà Nội, with her husband and four children. Her husband repairs sewing machines at home, while their eldest child is studying in university. Mrs Tuoi makes and sells Gato cakes and betrothal gifts, and her family has a monthly income of about 6.000.000 vnd. She has participated in SEDA for four years, always repaying loans on time. This time, she wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND (about 375 USD) to invest in her Gato cake shop.

loans.use: To invest in her Gato cake shop.

loans.name: Mahboba Group

texts.en:
Mahboba is the group leader of Mahboba. There are two members in this group. Each of them would like to borrow money for their own business.

Mahboba wants to take out a loan to enlarge her bakery. Zabyalah would like a loan to buy necessary materials for his tailor shop. Both of them want to thank all the Kiva lenders who are giving support to poor people in Afghanistan and helping businesses to progress.

loans.use: To enlarge her bakery

loans.name: Domitila De La Paz

texts.es: Domitila De La Paz P. R., reside en la capital de país San Salvador. A sus 33 años de edad Domitila es madre soltera de cuatro niños, todos aun menores de edad, Domitila afortunadamente cuenta con el apoyo de su madre Doña María quien ayuda a cuidando a sus pequeños nietos; mientras Domitila tiene que salir a trabajar día a día, para poder sacar adelante a sus hijos, que solo cuentan con el apoyo económico de ella. Domitila posee su propio negocio, es un puesto en el mercado central, donde vende variedad de ropa. El crédito que Domitila solita es para surtir con nueva mercadería, para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Domitila De La Paz P. R. lives in the capital of the country, San Salvador. She is 33, single, and has four children who are still minors. Fortunately, Domitilia can count on her mother, María, for help. María helps take care of her small grandchildren when Domitila has to leave to work day to day. She works for her children’s future; she provides their sole support. Domitila has her own business, a stall in the central market where she sells a variety of clothing. The loan that Domitila is asking for is to stock up on new merchandise to offer her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Lan Thị Đỗ was born in 1960. She lives in Xóm Chợ, Uy Nỗ, Đông Anh, Hà Nội with her son’s family. Her husband has been dead for a long time. She has two small grandsons. Mrs. Lan has a store. Her son is a bicycle mechanic. Together they sell bicycle parts. They have an income of about 5,000,000 VND.  She would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy bicycle parts to sell.

loans.use: To buy bicycle parts to sell

loans.name: Cate's Group

texts.en: Cate B. is a group leader.  She is a 60-year-old lady and a widow with four children between 28 and 35 years old. She is a strong and hard-working lady who has managed to provide an education for her children – even the least educated is a Diploma holder.  She also takes care of three grandchildren. She has been a businesswoman involved in the sale of matooke (green bananas) from Mukono for 10 years now and she is able to make 35,000 UGX in weekly profits. She hopes to open up other branches that could earn more income to help pay for her grandchildren’s school fees and furnish her home. Cate needs a loan to help purchase matooke in order to expand her business and increase profitability.

loans.use: Buying more green bananas for resale.

loans.name: Manuel Antonio

texts.es: Manuel Antonio P. S. reside en municipio de Ilopango del departamento de San Salvador. Salvador es un hombre de 37 años de edad, felizmente casado con  María quien le ayuda en el negocio, con ellos viven sus dos hijas Osiris de 10 años y Malani de 5 años de edad, ambas niñas se encuentran estudiando. Manuel posee una tienda ubicada en su casa, el negocio posee una clientela estable por no tener competencia cercana. El crédito que solicita Manuel es para surtir su tienda con variedad de productos.
texts.en:
Manuel Antonio P. S. lives in the Ilopango municipality in the San Salvador department. Manuel, 37, is happily married to Maria. She helps him in the business. Their two daughters, ten year old Osiris and five year old Malani, live with them. Both girls go to school. Manuel has a store, which is located in his house. The business has steady customers because there is no nearby competition. The loan that Manual is asking for is to stock his store with a variety of products.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock his business

loans.name: Lelibeth

texts.en:
Lelibeth E. is from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. She is 28 years old. Lelibeth is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Lelibeth owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the business’s only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business is selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Lelibeth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2009, Lelibeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and for the ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lelibeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional snacks to sell

loans.name: Lam

texts.en:
Lam T. N. was born in 1952 ( id: 010117090047 ) lives in Dai Bi, Uy No, which is southeast of Dong Anh in the Red River Delta region north of Ha Noi. Her family includes her son and daughter-in-law, both of whom work, and two grandsons.Mrs Lam grows rice and raises pigs. In her free time, she looks for work. Her family has a monthly income of about 5,000,000 VND. 

Mrs Lam is one of a five-member group requesting a loan from SEDA. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND (about 300 USD) to buy food for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy food for her pigs

loans.name: María Dolores

texts.es: María Dolores A. D. C., resiD. en municipio D. Ilopango del departamento D. San Salvador. María tiene 37 años D. edad, vive junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos. María ha montado su propio negocio desD. su casa, el cual le permite trabajar y a la vez no descuidar a sus hijos que tanto necesitan del cuido D. su madre, María maneja un inventario en productos D. belleza; como perfumes, cremas corporales, maquillaje, entre otros. El crédito que solicita María es para surtir su inventario con nueva mercadería para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
María Dolores A. D. C. lives in the Ilopango department in San Salvador. María, 37, lives with her husband and their three children. María set up her own business from her house. This allows her to work and take care of her children, who greatly need their mother’s care, at the same time. María maintains an inventory of beauty products like perfumes, body creams, make up, and others. The loan that María is asking for is to stock her inventory with new merchandise to offer her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her inventory

loans.name: Patricia Yolanda

texts.es: Patricia Yolanda P. D. F. resiD. en Soyapango  municipio D. San Salvador. Patricia vive con su esposo Carlos quien es empleado y su suegra Doña Luz D. 89 años D. edad, que por su edad necesita D. la compañía y cuidos D. su nuera. Patricia se dedica a la fabricación D. ropa D. cama, la cual después D. estar terminada sale a ofrecer a diferentes colonias cercanas, el destino del crédito que solicita Patricia es para comprar tela D. primera calidad, para cumplir con pedidos que sus clientes le están solicitando constantemente.
texts.en:
Patricia Yolanda resides in Soyapango, a municipality of San Salvador. She lives with her husband Carlos who is employed and her mother-in-law Luz who is 89 years of age and needs the company and care of her daughter-in-law.

Patricia makes bed clothes. The finished product is sold in various nearby neighborhoods. She is requesting a loan to buy first quality cloth, to fulfill orders which her customers are constantly soliciting.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY QUALITY CLOTH FOR MAKING BED CLOTHES

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
S. is a 39-year-old man, married to Srey, age 35. The couple has three school-aged children, and the children are dependent on their income. Currently, S. grows a certain type of bean and morning glory, which he harvests and collects when they mature.

S. hopes to earn extra income by investing as a pig trader, but he lacks the capital. Therefore, through HKL, he is asking for a loan from Kiva to buy a piglet to raise, and to purchase additional crop seeds.

loans.use: To buy a piglet, and purchase crop seeds

loans.name: Rosa Nidia

texts.es: Rosa Nidia V. D. R., resiD. en Ilopango municipio del departamento D. San Salvador. Rosa tiene 37 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos Andy D. 14 años, Adán D. 11 años y la pequeña Nidia D. 3 años D. edad. Rosa monto su negocio hace cuatro años, el cual está ubicado en su casa, siendo esta la única manera D. poder trabajar y cuidar D. sus hijos a la vez. Rosa posee una tienda por la cual hoy solita un crédito ya que desea surtirla con más variedad D. mercadería, que le permitan mejorar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Rosa Nidia V. D. R. lives in the Ilopango municipality in the San Salvador depratment. Rosa, 37, lives with her husband and their three children. Andy is 14, Adán is 11, and little Nidia is three. Rosa set up her business four years ago, and it is located in her house. It is the only way she is able to work and take care of her children at the same time. Rosa has a store. She is asking for a loan because she wants to stock it with a greater variety of merchandise. This will allow her to increase sales. .

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Jose Dagoberto

texts.es: Jose Dagoberto C. R., reside en Soyapango  municipio de San Salvador. Jose tiene 51 años de edad, vive con su extensa familia conformada por su esposa doña Ana, sus tres hijos, un pequeño nieto de 3 años de edad y su suegro. Jose se dedica a la profesión que aprendió hace varios y con la cual ha logrado sostener su familia; posee su propio negocio, un taller de carpintería, el cual se ha ido expandiendo por la experiencia y calidad de los muebles que fabrica Jose; el destino del crédito que solita Jose es para comprar suficiente madera que le permita elaborar una nueva producción de muebles, que están siendo exigidos por sus clientes.
texts.en:
Jose Dagoberto C. R. lives in the municipality of Soyapango in San Salvador. Jose is 51 years old and lives with his large family, including his wife Mrs. Ana, their three children, a small grandson of who is 3 years old and his father-in-law. Jose pursues the profession that he learned several years ago and with which he has succeeded in sustaining his family. He owns his own business, a carpentry workshop, which he has been expanding through his experience and the quality of the furniture that he makes. This loan that Jose is requesting is to buy enough wood so that he can make a more furniture, which his clients demand.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make furniture

loans.name: Nuluyat's Group

texts.en: N. Nuluyat is a 41 year old lady, married with five children between the ages of 7 and 20. Her oldest is pursuing a degree at university. She is a hardworking and courageous lady with a retail shop business that she has been running from Kirinya-Bombe in Mukono for 10 years. Out of her sales, Nuluyat is able to make 200,000/= monthly profit, and this income has been instrumental in ensuring that her family is not lacking. She has a dream of expanding her shop further to ensure that her children can attain the best of education through her careful savings. She needs a loan to be able to stock her retail shop with more goods like sugar, salt, cooking oil, paraffin and other goods.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods

loans.name: Nelson Antonio

texts.es: Nelson Antonio B. M. reside en Soyapango  municipio de San Salvador. Nelson tiene 29 años de edad, vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos Nelson junior de 5 años de edad y Teresita de 6 meses de nacida. Por la escasa preparación académica de Nelson se le ha sido muy difícil poder conseguir un empleo y es por eso que se decidió a poner un pequeño negocio, donde vende video juegos, recargas celulares de diferentes compañías y accesorios para celulares. El crédito que solicita Nelson es para invertir en productos de telefonía celular ya que son muy demandados.
texts.en:
Nelson Antonio B. M. lives in the municipality of Soyapango in San Salvador. Nelson is 29 years old and lives with his wife and two children; Nelson Jr. is 5 years old and Teresita is 6 month old. Because Nelson does not have a lot of education, it has been very difficult for him to find a job. Because of this, he decided to start a small business, where he sells video games, top up their cell phones, and sells cell phone accessories. The loan that Nelson is requesting is to invest in cell phone products since those have the highest demand.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply his business

loans.name: Farkhanda Group

texts.en:
Farkhanda is the group leader of the Farkhanda group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their own business activities.  Leyna and Leyda want to take a loan for their tailoring business.  Farkhanda would like to take a loan for her business of vegetable selling. They all want to see progress in their business in order to earn more money to support their families. 

They say that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to expand their businesses

loans.name: Magdalena De Jesús

texts.es: Magdalena D. Jesús R. D.
texts.en: Magdalena D. Jesús R. D.

loans.use: To supply her store

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie A. is a 30-year-old woman from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. Rosemarie is married and has an infant-aged child. To make a living, Rosemarie owns and operates a business in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Her main source of business income comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years, and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

Rosemarie joined HSPFI in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation, and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Rosemarie's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from new products to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory

loans.name: Maricela Elizabeth

texts.es: Maricela Elizabeth G. D. Q., resiD. en Ilopango municipio del departamento D. San Salvador. Maricela es una mujer casada con 32 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y su hija Johana D. 2 años D. edad. Maricela ha instalado una tienda en su casa, la cual le permite obtener ingresos y a su vez poder compartir y cuidar D. su hija todos los días. El crédito que solicita Maricela es comprar nueva mercadería para surtir su negocio y aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Maricela Elizabeth G. D. Q. lives in the municipality of Ilopango in the department of San Salvador. Maricela is married, 32 years old, and lives with her husband and 2 year old daughter, Johana. Maricela has opened a store in her house, allowing her to make some money and at the same time take care of her daughter everyday. The loan that Maricela is asking for would be used to stock her store with new merchandise and thus increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for sale in store.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza D. C. is a 35-year-old woman from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan city. Analiza is married and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, Analiza owns and operates a business making and selling food. Her main source of income comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Analiza has been engaged in her business for over 4 years, and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month.

Analiza joined HSPFI in 2009 to access financial services to help improve her living situation, and her ability to engage in business activities. Analiza successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. The previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be Analiza's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the revenue generated from the additional business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
V., age 30, is a village man living in Pursat Province. He is a local crop farmer, growing rice, vegetables, and some fruit on his own farmland.

To help meet his family's daily expense needs, his wife sells cooking supplies to neighbors from home for a profit. V. now has one son who is still not enrolled in school. Because selling grocery items is the main source of family income, V. is applying for a loan which will enable his wife to purchase additional inventory for sale. He proposes to use the leftover part of the loan to buy a pig to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for his wife's business

loans.name: Jose Edgardo

texts.es: Jose Edgardo H. A. de 55 años de edad,  reside en Santa Tecla municipio del departamento de La Libertad. Jose vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos. Jose es un hombre visionario en su negocio, se dedica a la producción y comercialización de almohadas, las cuales son distribuidas en una cadena de supermercados del país, el deseo de Jose es seguir creciendo en su negocio y que su producto entre a muchos hogares, es por eso que Jose solicita este crédito, para la compra de materia prima,que le permita aumentar la producción de sus almohadas y poder empezar a expandir su distribución a otros destinos.
texts.en:
Jose Edgardo H. A. is 55 years old and lives in the town of Santa Tecla in the department of La Libertad. He lives with his wife and his two children. Jose is a visionary man in his line of work, producing and selling pillows that are then resold in a chain of supermarkets throughout the country. Jose wishes to keep growing his business and to get his product into even more homes. For these reasons he is asking for this loan, to buy raw materials that will allow him to increase his production of pillows and begin to expand his distribution to more destinations.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw material in order to expand a business.

loans.name: Tobietha

texts.en:
Tobietha is a member of the Tanganyika  borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 9 and 4 years old.She also cares for other 2 dependents.

Tobietha has owned a shop business for 10 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 250,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Tobietha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 In order to buy shop commodities like salt, rice, maize, cooking oil etc.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of  this loan, Tobietha hopes to save more money, pay school fess, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shop commodities

loans.name: Edward's Group

texts.en:
S. Edward is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is 54 years old and married with 10 children aged 28 – 3 years, and he takes care of one orphan.  Edward is a farmer, and at the same time lays bricks for building houses. 

In the farming business, he has been involved in poultry for 30 years and he also keeps cattle.  His main challenge is the seasonality of his business and the lack of accessibility to the big markets.  However, he is able to make 140,000/= as weekly profits and these are and have been helpful in looking after his family. Edward’s main key to success is the fact that he has high quality products.  

His goal is to expand his businesses further by having more birds and cows for fattening. For the bricks, he employs men to help him lay the bricks.  He needs a loan to help employ men to mingle the soil for brick laying as well as buy pesticides for his farm.

loans.use: Employing labor to mingle soil for brick laying and pesticides for farming.

loans.name: Paulita

texts.en:
Paulita is a very diligent entrepreneur from the village of Ineangan, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Isaias and is very determined in helping her husband in uplifting their living condition to be able to give their three children a better future. Two of her children have already finished their college education and are presently applying for a job while the youngest is still studying in the secondary level of education.

Paulita manages a food-vending business in front of their house. She cooks different viands (tasty dishes) and some snacks to generate income that will help them meet their daily needs and support the education of their youngest. Her husband, on the other hand, cultivates their land twice a year by planting rice and some vegetables.

Paulita is now asking to borrow PHP 15,000 from Kiva lenders to be used as additional capital for her business. She is positive that lenders will grant her the financial assistance that she needs. She always believes that hard work and patience are some of the factors that will make her business grow and enable her to become successful.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

location.town: Ineangan Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Dodovico's Group

texts.en:
K. Dodovico is a 60-year-old hardworking man, married with 18 children between the ages of 8 and 35, and he takes care of two dependants. He has been involved in the supply of charcoal to schools and to retailers for 21 years. They take in small quantities and, as a result, he makes 60,000/= weekly profits. He is an honest man who delivers on time, and this has won him customers and contracts. He has a dream of increasing his supplies and lobbying for more school and hospital contracts so that he can make more profit from his business.

Dodovico is the leader of his group in Mukono. Dodovico needs a loan to be able to buy more charcoal from the villages for his customers.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema is a member of the Tanganyika borrower group in Kinyambo, Iringa, she is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 14, 11, 7, 3 years old.

Neema has owned a shop business selling commodities like beans, wheat, salts etc for 12 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Neema`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more  shop commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Neema hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shop commodities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Michell

texts.en:
“Learn to sacrifice to make your dreams come true,” says Michell A. from the village of Ineangan, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 25 years old and only finished her high school education. In spite of this, she remains optimistic and she works hard to be able to earn a living for her family.

Michell manages a village store as her source of living. For her business to grow, she would like to borrow 8,000 PHP from Kiva lenders that she will invest in her business. She is glad that she can earn a weekly income of 1,250 PHP. Though her income is too little, she is thankful for being able to maintain her business and being able to save funds for her education. She hopes that lenders will allow her to borrow money to help with her business.

loans.use: Additional business capital

location.town: Ineangan Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Lucas

texts.en:
Lucas O., 37 years old, is married to Lucy Awino. He has been painting and repairing vehicles for the last ten years in Naivasha.

Lucas was unable to obtain financial aid from other institutions. Then he learned about KADET through a friend who is already a client and was able to acquire his first loan. With it he intends to buy a painting machine. Lucas aspires to own his own garage one day.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET at: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a painting machine

loans.name: Sylivia's Group

texts.en: Sylivia S. is a hardworking and determined 29-year-old who has owned a beauty salon in Kabembe for 7 years. One of her secrets of success is stocking her salon with the necessary equipment for her customers to get everything they need in one place, for example she has hair dryers, a steamer, combs, weaves, and braids. She is a smart businesswoman and her goal is to expand her salon so she can double her weekly profits.  To achieve this goal, Sylivia needs a loan which she will use to restock her saloon with more hair products like chemicals, braids, and weaves.

loans.use: To restock her beauty salon.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en: Margarita strives very hard in her sales businesses so she can improve her family’s economic condition. She is married to Johny and they are blessed with one child named Jomar.  She hopes to earn enough income to finance the education of her son until he earns a college degree.  In this regard, she requests a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5000 for her fruit and vegetable business. Her husband Johny helps her with the business by maintaining their small fruits and vegetable farm.  Helping each other is very necessary and Margarita is thankful for having a husband like Johny. Margarita also sells cooked foods and snacks inside the school campus, and she also sells charcoal.  Her businesses are very beneficial to them.  She wants to continue improving her businesses and hopes that her loan request will be approved.

loans.use: To expand her sales businesses.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Tanganyika borrower group in Kinayanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 9 and 4 years old.

Maria has owned a maize business for 5 years, she works  12 hours a day and  she earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Maria`s first loan  from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 100,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Maria hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize

loans.name: Richel

texts.en:
Richel M. is from the village of Dalapang, Ozamiz City.  Richel, 28, is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Richel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting cassava for sale.  Richel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Richel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Richel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC.  Richel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her child and save the remainder as a reserve for future needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en: Rosalia manages a general store in the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. She is a responsible housewife and mother to her children. She hopes that her children will earn college degrees so they can get good jobs and have pleasant living conditions.  Her husband works as a driver in Tabuk, Kalinga Apayao.  To help improve her general store, Rosalia requests a loan of PHP5,000 from KIVA lenders.  She hopes that her requested loan will be granted so she can better maintain her store.

loans.use: To improve her general store.

loans.name: Jackie's Group

texts.en: Jackie M. is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a hardworking and determined lady managing two businesses at once. She sells both new and old clothes at various daily markets in and around Mukono.  Selling at multiple locations helps increase profitability.  Jackie also is in the bricklaying business.  Mostly she employs laborers to handle this business under her direct supervision. Running two businesses has helped her pay for the education of her children plus their other needs like clothing, food, and medical care. Jackie needs a loan to buy more clothes for resale as well as to employ men to mingle soil for bricklaying.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale and to pay more laborers.

loans.name: Huong's Group

texts.en:
Hương Thị Nguyễn was born in 1965.  She lives in Xuan Trach village with her husband and two children. Her husband is a builder.  Her son and daughter are workers. They have a stabL. income.  She is farmer who stays at home and breeds pigs and cows. She has a monthly income of about 5,000,000 VND. She is the group leader of a seven member group loan offered by SEDA. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  At this time, she wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy food for her cows. 
 
Luật Thị Vũ was born in 1978. She has one child. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to breed pigs and poultry.

Hương Thị Nguyễn was born in 1957.  She has three children. She raises chickens. She needs 5,450,000 VND to buy food for the chickens.

 Chín Thị Lê was born in 1978. She has two children. She is a tailor. She needs 5,450,000 VND to buy fabric.

Thu Thị Nguyễn was born in 1970. She has two children.  She needs 5,450,000 VND to breed pigs and poultry.

Chi Thị Nguyễn was born in 1977. She has two children. She sells vegetables in the market.  She needs 5,450,000 VND for her small business.
 
Hoa K. Nguyễn was born in 1967. She has two children. She needs 5,886,000 VND to buy goods to sell.

loans.use: to buy food for cows.

loans.name: Happy

texts.en:
Happy is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinayanambo, Iringa. She is 25 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 10 years old.

Happy has owned a shop business for 5 years,  she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Happy`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Happy hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy shop commodities

loans.name: Suzan's Group

texts.en: Suzan N. is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is a businesswoman and tailor who works mainly at the Kyetume trading center.  She also makes juice for sale.  With the tailoring business, she makes tailor-made dresses, skirts, and blouses as well as mending torn clothes.  In Mukono where her home is located, she makes and packs juice that she sells to shops, supermarkets, and schools.  Working two jobs helps bring in extra income, especially when one business is in a low season. She also buys some clothing for her tailoring business, which customers then buy from her.  She plans to use the loan to purchase more clothes for resale, and to buy threads and needles for tailoring.

loans.use: To buy clothing, threads, and needles.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
It is hard to be a single parent to five children, even when they are already adults. You still have to guide them and act as both mother and father to them. This is the experience of Mrs. Corazon O., a 57-year-old widow who lives in the village of Tuburan, in the town of Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. Four of her five children have their own families and earn their own living. The youngest is 21 years old and still lives with her while she is attending college.

Corazon has owned and managed a pottery business for more than 30 years. She has a loyal clientele that patronizes her business because they know she produces high quality pottery in designs and colors that are suited to their taste.  But being successful can sometimes create problems - good ones!  Because of the high demand for her products, she ran short on working capital.  She did not want to miss the opportunity to expand her business, and this is the reason why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 - to have access to additional capital when she has large orders that require a lot of raw materials.

In addition to her pottery business, she diversified and opened a cafeteria so that she could earn additional income. In the five years that she has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has maintained her good credit performance, and she earns on average a net profit of PHP5000 per month. Her last loan of PHP14000 was fully paid on time.  Now on her 9th loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP15000 to infuse more working capital into her business ventures. Her main objective now is to have her youngest son graduate from college and start his own life. Corazon is also starting to save for herself so that she will not be a burden to her children when she grows old.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To expand her business ventures.

loans.name: Nicolasa Antonia

texts.es: Nicolasa Antonia G. U. de 53 años de edad, reside en Cojutepeque municipio del departamento de Cuscatlán. Nicolasa vive solamente con su hija Ana de 24 años de edad. Nicolasa posee un negocio de venta de productos plásticos, ubicado en el mercado de Cojutepeque, son 17 años de experiencia que Nicolasa posee como comerciante mismos años que hoy le dan la ventaja sobre otros negocios; ya que Nicola es muy conocida en la zona y como resultado sus clientes son estables. El crédito que solicita Nicolasa es para invertirlo en su negocio, con la compra de nueva mercadería para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Nicolasa Antonia G. U. is 53 years old and lives in the town of Cojutepeque, in the department of Cuscatlán. Nicolasa lives only with her 24 year old daughter, Ana. She owns a small store where she sells plastic products, located in the Cojutepeque market. Nicolasa has 17 years of experience working as a shopkeeper, and this experience gives her an advantage over other competitors, as she is very well known in the area and has a stable group of customers. The loan that Nicolasa is asking for would be invested in her business through the purchase of new merchandise to sell to her clientele.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her shop with new merchandise.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is 48 years old and married with 4 children. She sells dried fish. Dried fish is used in the preparation of soup in Nigeria. The demands for her dried fish are high and she hopes to meet the demands of customers. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more dried fish to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda M. is from the village of Montol, Ozamiz City. She is 38-years-old. Erlinda is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a retail "sari-sari" general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste.  Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities.  Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from GDMPC.  Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell as well as to invest in the expansion of her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children and to save for future emergencies. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and invest to expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Mrs. Gemma G. is from Mabini, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She has two children ages 18 and 19 years old. She started her general store 18 years ago selling small volumes of soft drinks and other beverages. Then in the later years she focused on being a wholesaler of all kinds of beverages. Now she is earning PHP 10,000 per month from the general store and her soft drink business.

Gemma is planning to expand her soft drink business and will be needing additional capital to increase her inventory.  This is why, for her 8th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has applied to borrow PHP 18,000.   

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel is 36 years old and married with 5 children. She has a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen B. is from the village of Del Carmrn, Iligan City. She is 35 years old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Ellen runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Ellen has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

Ellen joined HSPFI earlier this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ellen successfully repaid her first HSPFI loan of 5000 PHP which she used to expand her product offering. Ellen is now requesting her 2nd loan, for 8000 PHP, so she can buy more products to sell.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Noeun Siv Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
A village bank, which consists of seventeen people and is requesting a bank loan, is located in Trapeang Ampil village in Kandal province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Noeun S. is the village bank president. She owns a poultry business. Her husband, Mr. Sao Horn, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectar field of land used to cultivate rice. Mrs. Noeun S. is requesting a loan to buy some chickens, ducks, and fertilizer to support the field. She is 53 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a farmer while the other is employed in a garment factory.

Fifteen members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy some chickens, ducks, and fertilizer to support the field.

loans.name: Rose Nyambura

texts.en:
Rose is married to John M., who is a businessman. The couple has three children, aged 15, 12 and 7. Rose has been operating her retail shop for a while now. Her business is strategically placed and thus she is able to serve many customers. 

Rose was introduced to KADET through existing clients. She does not have a previous credit history with any other micro-finance institution. She has applied for a loan, which she plans to use to add stock to her retail shop with things like tea leaves, soya and coffee. With the extra profits, Rose wants to open a stall to buy bulk stock thus getting maximum profits.

Rose believes that she is very hardworking and thus her future hopes and dreams are to start another business of selling cereals to add the family income.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to add stock of tea leaves, soya and coffee.

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane M. is a friendly and hardworking lady with a poultry-farm business in Kireka. She has been in this business for three years, plus she has been an agricultural farmer for a long time. She is 47 years old and married with seven children between the ages of 4 and 20 as she takes care of other orphans. 

Her biggest challenge is the lack of enough capital to expand both her businesses. This has kept her to a profit margin of 400,000 Ugandan shillings a month. She works so hard to ensure that she expands her businesses by having more chickens, both layers and broilers, plus being a large-scale farmer. 

All her children go to school and she is a strong force at home in ensuring that all school dues are cleared on time. Jane needs a loan to help buy more day-old chicks and also buy their feed so as to continue with her expansion process.

loans.use: Buying more day-old chicks and feed for her farm expansion

loans.name: Elpidio

texts.en:
Elpidio, or Jhun as he is also called, resides in the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. He is 23 years old. He finished only his high school education due to lack of financial resources. So he decided to work and save some of his income so he can pursue his studies. 

Jhun is a frozen-food vendor. His parents gave him a small amount of capital to start his own business. He purchases his products in the public market of Solano and sells them at a retail price in their village by going house to house. With his sacrifices, he is able to earn a weekly gross income of 1,500 Philippine pesos (about $32). He spends some of his income for his basic needs and saves the rest for his education.  

He aims to purchase more products to sell but he lacks the capital. He would like to seek financial assistance from Kiva lenders with a loan amount of PHP5,000 for business improvement. He hopes that through this, his business will continue to progress.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita A. is from the city of Tinago, Ozamiz City. She is 44 years old. Amelita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Amelita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Amelita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Amelita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa L. is a 36-year-old farmer and has three kids. Her eldest is nine years old, and all are studying in elementary school. She started helping her husband till the land on their farm to be able to meet their needs. Currently, they have a two-hectare rice field, and she says that it needs to be plowed well so that the plants will grow well.

She would like to ask for a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to pay the laborers who helped toil on the farm during land preparation.

She said that she likes CEVI's services a lot because it has the lowest interest rate.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Emeliano

texts.en:
Emeliano A. is from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. He is 51 years old. Emeliano is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Emeliano owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to local community members. Emeliano has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Emeliano joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emeliano is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide services. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emeliano from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Monica Ndunge

texts.en:
Monica is a widow and she has three children. She has been in the charcoal business for six years, in a very busy estate which is highly populated. This ensures that her business has big sales and returns. Her charcoal business is her only source of income.

Monica was introduced to KADET through existing clients, and she has had no loans from other MFIs. She plans to use the loan that she has applied for to increase her charcoal stock, and with the extra profit, Monica will develop her piece of land. Her future hope is to become a landlady, which she believes is very possible as she is very hardworking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions for micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Increasing her stock of charcoal so as to maximize profits

loans.name: Arnylyne

texts.en: Arnylyne is married to Elmer, and they are living in Labni, Mabuslo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. Both of them are only high-school graduates because they got married at an early age. They had a difficult life because they were both jobless during that time, until their parents gave them a small farm lot and encouraged them to plant vegetables so they would have a source of income. Since then, Arnylyne has started a vegetable vending business. With a small amount of capital, she acquires her products from Bambang public market, and sometimes she also sells their harvested vegetables. To further improve her business, she is now hoping to avail of a loan of 5,000.00 PHP from KIVA lenders. She hopes that through her business, they can continue to meet the needs of their two children and also save something for their future.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Mrs. Vantha Mak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Vantha M. Village Bank group is made up of eleven people from Smaong Village in Takeo Province. Each person will use their share of this loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Vantha M. is the bank president, selected by the members. She is also a rice soup seller and a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Ly Keo, is a farmer and taxi driver. The couple has two children, one of whom attends the local school, and another who is too young to work or study.

Vantha is applying for a loan to buy pig food and piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living with this loan.

loans.use: To buy pig food and piglets for breeding

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: S. is a 33-year-old woman and mother. To make a living, she retails fish and meatballs that she buys in bulk from her wholesale supplier and typically earns an average of US $3 per day. She is married with six children; all of them are going to school. Her husband helps be responsible for the family by fishing around Tunle Sap Lake. The family’s living conditions are not comfortable because their house is too old and small for them. S. has been planning to build a new house for a long time, but her personal savings are not sufficient to pay for construction. Therefore, she would like a loan of US $1200 to add to her savings in order to begin building a new house.

loans.use: To begin building a new house

loans.name: María Martina

texts.es: María Martina D. L., reside en Colon municipio del departamento de La Libertad. María es una mujer muy trabajadora,  con sus conocimientos básicos de sumar y restar administra su negocio, el cual tiene ubicado en el mercado de Santa Tecla donde su fuerte de ventas, es el pollo y los embutidos, aunque también tiene productos como aceite, huevos, entre otros. El crédito que María solicita es para comprar mayor cantidad de pollo y embutidos para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
María Martina D. L. lives in the town of Colon, in the department of La Libertad. María is a hard-working woman, who, with her basic knowledge of addition and subtraction, administers her business. Her shop is located in the Santa Tecla market, where she mainly sells chicken and sausages, but also sells products like oil and eggs, among other things. The loan that María is asking for would be used for the purchase of more chicken and sausages to stock up her business.
