Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing more products to expand the business.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena dreams of providing a progressive life for her family. She wants her children to have a better future life, so she and her husband are working very hard. She is married to Lorenzo Jr. and they are aiming to improve their poor living conditions for the benefit of their three children. 

Her husband is operating a tricycle transport business while Lucena sells frozen foods. She started with a small capital amounting to PHP 2,000 and she is thankful that she has been able to maintain her enterprise. She is hoping for business growth but she needs additional capital. This is the reason why she is asking for a financial capital of PHP5, 000.00. With her efforts and sacrifices in the business, she believes that she can reach her dreams.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita manages a simple village store, while her husband, Jayson, works as an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker) in Dubai. She is a responsible housewife living in Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 28 years old and a high school graduate. Rita is very determined to work so that she can help her husband earn a living. They strive to uplift their poor living conditions and save money for the welfare of their child.

With her husband’s remittance from abroad, Rita was able to put up the store, and she uses most of her income as rolling capital. Wanting to increase her income, she is now requesting financial assistance from Kiva lenders. She is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 as business capital. She hopes that, with this loan, her business will continuously progress.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante R. runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling food and daily use products in his community. He is 40 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Saray, Iligan City. Dante has been in his business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Dante joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dante is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This will be his first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Lesley

texts.en:
Lesley is married to Benny. They live in the village of Labni, Mabuslo in Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. They are blessed with three children: Benedick, Rhyzlyn and Clarissa Mae. Their eldest is now a first year high school student and the other two are in the elementary level.

Lesley sells vegetables and her husband operates a tricycle transport service. She and her husband work together to support the needs of their family, especially the education of their children.  

Her dream of a sustainable business gave her the idea of requesting a loan from Kiva lenders. She is requesting PHP 5,000 to use as additional capital to improve her business and to maintain their tricycle transport business. She is hoping that the lenders will grant her request.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok H. makes wooden furniture. He sells his finished product to buyers who come directly to his house and he  transports his furniture to sell around his community. He makes over 10 sets before selling out. He also orders baskets from the other villagers and sells them to make additional income. His wife stays at home to do housework and also helps him in the business. 

Recently, Sok H. has run out of essential materials from his stock supply and he hopes to acquire other raw materials to continue making furniture. He depends on using his Kiva loan as an advance. Sok H. is a 49-year-old married man blessed with four children; three of whom are married. Two of Sok H.'s children are employed. His eldest daughter works in garment industry and his second son is a carpenter.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make furniture

loans.name: Myrnaflor

texts.en:
Like any mother, Myrnaflor D. dreams of a bright future for her children. She has seven children, the eldest of whom is 16 years old,  and a very supportive husband who helps her manage her rice field. She hopes that her rice can provide for her family's basic needs, such as food, clothing and school supplies.

She would like to request a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and to pay the laborer who helped them till their rice field. 

Receiving this loan will enable her family to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Gerelmaa

texts.en:
Gerelmaa Chimiddorj is 55 years old and lives with her husband in their apartment in Arkhangai Province in central Mongolia. They have raised their two children, who are now fully grown and live on their own. 

Gerelmaa operates a sewing business in her town with the help of her retired husband. She provides new, neat and inexpensive clothes to her many customers and is best known for her dressmaking. Gerelmaa started her sewing businss in 1996 with capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~$36 USD). She has worked hard and has steadily grown her business over the years. Because the sewing business is the only source of income for her and her husband, it is vital that Gerelmaa increase her sales and invest more in her business to continue their quality of life. 

Gerelmaa is very passionate about her trade and loves the work. She says,"Sewing clothes for others makes me the happiest person." For the future, she hopes to increase the variety of clothes that she produces to attract new customers. She is requesting a 100,000 tugrug ($75 USD) loan to buy more thread, materials, fabrics and needles for her sewing business.

loans.use: To buy more thread, materials, fabrics and needles

loans.name: Purevjav

texts.en:
N. Purevjav is 59 years old. He lives with his wife, two sons, and his granddaughter in a single ger (a yurt or Mongolian nomadic tent home) in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. His sons currently attend university. 

Purevjav operates a mobile food service business in his town, with the help of his wife. The business is very family oriented because Purevjav and his wife make all of their food and drink products at their home and then deliver them to their customers. 

Purevjav started his business in early 2009 with 80,000 tugrugs (~$57 USD) of capital. He has worked very hard and has found success in a short time since starting the business. Currently, his working capital exceeds 400,000 tugrugs (~$280 USD) 

This success has allowed Puravjav to provide for his sons' education. He said, "Education is the most important thing that one must possess in order to have decent and happy life." For the future, Purevjav hopes to continue to grow his businss and provide a quality life for his family. His dream is to one day open his own cafe in his town.

He is requesting a loan of 700,000 tugrug (~ $490 USD) to purchase supplies for his mobile food service business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for his mobile food service business

loans.name: Narmandakh

texts.en:
Narmandakh K. lives with her three sons and her husband in a ger (a yurt or Mongolian nomadic dwelling) in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her three sons all attend university, which makes it difficult for them to earn enough money. 

Several years ago, she sold clothes outdoors by putting her products on a table. But, by working deligently, she made enough money to buy a counter in a shop, which was much nicer and much more comfortable than sitting outside. She bought her counter in 2000 and now she conducts her business with her husband. 

The secret of her business success is her smile. This makes her customers buy their clothes only from her. She is a very kind and polite person who always tries hard to give people happiness. She wants all her three children to be very helpful to the people around them. So she always tells them to make people happy and make them trust you. After that, your business will flourish without any obstacles. 

She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug ($725 USD) loan to continue her business, which is only source of income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase men's and women's apparel

loans.name: Norjmaa

texts.en:
Norjmaa lives with her three children and husband in a yurt-like Mongolian nomadic dwelling called a "ger" in the Chigeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband helps her with her business and her three children attend university and high school. 

Norjmaa is a salesperson. She started her business in 2000 in the Huchit Shonhor Market, one of the biggest local markets. She also has a little shop near her home that is managed by her children. Her husband is also very good at making wooden products, thus adding profits to their family earnings. She also buys animal fat in enormous amounts and makes cooking oils. 

She truly wants to increase her business profits and to contribute them for her children's future. Her dream is to make her counter bigger and redesign and repair their home to be more comfortable for all of the family members. She is requesting a 1, 000,000 tugrug ($725 USD) loan to purchase more products to sell and to repair her home.

loans.use: To purchase more food products to sell and to repair her home.

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Otgonbayar L. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband is a lawyer and gives legal advice. He also sometimes works as a legal assistant. Otgonbayar is an English translator who had first worked at her sister's company and then, in 2004, started her own "Double" Co., Ltd translation company.

Her monthly revenues can be as high as 800,000 tugrug (~563 USD) with a net profit of 300,000 tugrug (~210 USD). She is working hard to open a new branch and still struggling to maintain and continue her business. One of the reasons for her success is that she is good at accounting.

One of her most important goals is to educate her children well so that they can lead their own lives without any difficulty. For that reason she is trying hard to increase the company's profit. She says that doing translation work for others is a very helpful thing to do. She states "I am happy to see smiling faces everyday". All of her customers are satisfied with the translation work that her company does for them. They say that they trust the translations done by Otgobayar's employees more than any other translating company.

Otgonbayer would like to purchase new dictionaries, computers and necessary stationary in order to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of her business. She is requesting a 2,600,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan.

loans.use: To purchase office equipment and supplies

loans.name: Kheav

texts.en:
Kheav M. is a widowed mother, 34 years old, and currently lives with her two teenage children in the province of Kompong Tom. To earn a living, she buys mats in bulk at reasonable cost from rural people to retail them by walking around the village of her community.

Kheav M. has been operating in this sector since 2005 and usually earns an average of US $3.50. To make more profit, Kheav M. is looking for a loan to use as capital to accumulate a quantity of mats to resell.

loans.use: To accumulate a quantity of mats to resell

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun O. is a decent person with a good personality. She lives with her husband and two daughters in Kharkhorin, which was the ancient capital city of Mongolia at one time. Her oldest daughter graduated from university last year and is looking for a job. Her younger daughter is still studying at a university and will graduate soon. She believes that one can lead a happy life by gaining education, so she earns all the money necessary for her children's education.

She is good at sewing traditional Mongolian shoes called Buriad Shoes that are just right for the cold Mongolian winter. She started her business 30 years ago. She works with her friend and they rent a small room where they make and sew the shoes. When winter comes, their business flourishes by getting many shoe orders from people, but in the summer time it is hard to manage their business because of the small number of orders. She is doing her best to expand her business and not to put any burdens on her two daughters. She is requesting 500,000 tugrug (~352 USD) to maintain her successful family business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen Y. currently makes rattan furniture. She is 57 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom province, located about 200 km from the capital, Phnom Penh. She has five children: two are married and three are single. Pen Y. saves up over 10 sets of rattan and then sells them to her customers for profit. Usually, her valued clients need to order a few days or a week in advance. Her husband helps her transport the finished products directly to customers' houses.

Pen Y. is facing a problem with transportation because she doesn't have her own vehicle for her and her family's riding requirement. Thus, she would like a loan in order to buy a used motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle

loans.name: Bayanjargal

texts.en:
D. Bayanjargal is a very polite and kind person who possesses good communication skills. She lives with her two daughters in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. Her oldest son went to the United States of America to work and earn money to help his family. Her two daughters study in high school, but they try hard to help their mother with her business whenever they can.

In 2002 she began her business of selling clothes with 300,000 tugrug ($210 USD) of working capital and managed it so well that it now exceeds 4,500,000 tugrug ($3100 USD). A good knowledge of accounting has helped her achieve her success. She travels several times a year to Beijing, China to purchase clothes, transporting them first to Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia and then to Arkhangai province, incurring substantial transportation expenses.

With considerable experience and knowledge in this business, she believes that it is important for Mongolia's development to promote owners of small and medium businesses. She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan to increase her sales and to expand her business even more.

loans.use: To purchase men's and women's apparel to sell

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en:
S. Lhagvasuren started a woolen and knitted-goods production business in January 2009 with two other people, producing small souvenirs. For now, they are running the business in the Service Center, but in the future they would like to purchase equipment and expand this business.

Lhagvasuren lives in Uvurkhangai province with three children: one son is serving in the army; one is a herder in the countryside, and her daughter goes to school. A healthy and diligent worker and good communicator with the ability to expand her business, Lhagvasuren is requesting 1,500,000 tugrugs (approx. $1040 USD) to purchase a knitting machine for 800,000 tugrugs and raw materials for 700,000 tugrugs. She would like to have her own workplace in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a knitting machine

loans.name: Miged

texts.en:
Miged D., who lives with his wife in Uvurkhangai province, located in the central part of Mongolia, was a driving teacher in the Defense Aide Association until he retired in 1996. Since that time, he has started a taxi service in the Arvaikheer Soum center and is now operating the business in the provincial center.

A good-natured and hardworking person, Miged has lived in his current home for 40 years and plans to continue operating his business in order to support the education of his two grandchildren. He is now requesting 1,000,000 tugrugs (approx. $690 USD) to purchase repair parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase repair parts for his car

loans.name: Gnep

texts.en:
C. is a 32-year-old living in the attractive territory of Kompong Tom Province. C. is a good father, caring for one lovely young child, while his wife, who appears in the picture, stays at home to be responsible for the daily housework and rattan basket making.

C. currently sells recycling goods that he buys from his villagers. C. will be using his first loan on Kiva through HKL to purchase a cow and raise its baby. Additionally, he will rent the cows out to farmers for fees.

loans.use: To purchase a cow and raise its baby

loans.name: Oyuntsetseg

texts.en:
T.Oyuntsetseg is a lathe operator who received her secondary education. In accordance with her occupation, she started her repair business in 1995 with the help of her husband. They live with their three daughters in a ger (Mongolian nomadic dwelling) in the Chingeltei District of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. This nomadic dwelling is quite small for 5 people.

They have a dream to buy more gers for their children when they get married and have their own lives. The oldest daughter studies at the Nursing College in order to become a very good nurse and help others. The other two daughters go to high school and study very hard in order to further their education and help their parents.

Oyuntsetseg's business is repairing and welding cars and iron goods. They also produce hand-made iron goods, such as chairs and shelves. With the iron goods, they earn 200,000 tugrug (~141 USD) and by repairing cars they earn approximately 300,000 to 500,000 tugrug (~210 USD - 350 USD) in a month. Since the start if the business, they have gained a great reputation among their customers. There is no one in their area unacquainted with them.

When people say "Huyga's home", everyone knows about whom they are talking. "It is significant to be good at one's occupation," says Oyuntsetseg, and that is true for everyone. They want to expand their business on behalf of their children's future. She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan to maintain and expand her car repair business.

loans.use: to maintain and expand her car repair business

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia B.'s main source of income comes from operating a tricycle transport service. She is 46 years old, widowed and has two adult children. She is from the town of Segatic Daku Clarin Misamis Occidental. Cecilia has been in this business for over 11 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Cecilia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair her vehicle to provide better service. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Tserendorj

texts.en:
Tserendorj B. is a very decent and reliable person who lives with his daughter and wife in Uvurkhangai province, Mongolia. He started his business in 2003, selling machinery parts with his daughter. Now he is conducting his business with his wife while his daughter has started a car repair service of her own. He is known by customers to be an honest seller and everyone in his province likes to buy machinery parts from him.

He wishes to increase his sales in order to earn more profit. Now he has one container and one counter to sell his machinery parts. His budget is around in 8,000,000 tugrug (~5600 USD). From this number, you can see how good he is at his business. He is considered in his community as very experienced and intelligent. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan to maintain and continue his business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina T., 33, is a rice grower from Veruela Agusan Del Sur. She has two children. Her eldest child is 12. Her husband is also a farmer that helps her manage the farm. She said that her CEVI loans help a lot to sustain her livelihood. She inherited the farm from her parents and hopes that it will provide for the needs of her family, especially food and clothing. 

Now she wants to grow her business. By taking a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos with CEVI, she will have the chance to grow her harvest. The loan will be used to pay the laborers as well as the owner of the equipment they used during land preparation.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Tsetsegee

texts.en:
Tsetsegee D. is a very hard-working woman who lives with her husband and two children in a ger (or Mongolian nomadic dwelling) in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband, Chinzorig, is unemployed and babysits their children at home. He owns a car that he sometimes uses to transport people from one place to another. Their two children attend school. Because neither child is in college yet, living expenses are much lower than people whose children go to college or university. 

Tsetsegee makes a living working as a tailor. She worked in a factory until 2003, then started her own business sewing and stitching people's clothes. Her monthly earnings are between 300,000-400,000 tugrugs ($210-290). She sews all kinds of European clothes and all forms of traditional Mongolian dress. Her dream is to finish building her house, which she is working on right now. To make this happen, she works hard to earn money. She has applied for a loan of $650 that she will use to expand her business and finish building her house.

loans.use: To expand her business and finish building her house

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Y. Tuya is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Her oldest son, Ganga, has lived and studied in Japan for the past six years, while her younger two daughters attend university and high school in Mongolia. Her husband works as carpenter in a small wooden-products factory in the city.  Tuya operates a jeans-selling business out of two rented stalls at a popular indoor market and trade center. She has a shop assistant who helps her operate both stalls. She also supplements her income by working as a Mongolian language teacher at a center for foreign nationals. 

Tuya started her jeans business in 2001 and has had much success. Today, her profits average between 400,000 - 500,000 tugrugs per month. She attributes her success to her good management and accounting practices. In the future, Tuya hopes to continue to grow her business so that she can provide for her children's education.  As the new school year has just begun, Tuya hopes to purchase more products to sell to the many students who will be buying new clothes this fall and winter. She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan ($2,150) to buy supplies for her jeans-selling business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her jeans-selling business.

loans.name: Uurtsaih

texts.en:
Ts. Uurtsaih is 38 years old and lives with her husband, son and daughter in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. Their home is a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of her children currently attend the local high school. Uurtsaih operates a mobile grocery store that sells products to people who live in her area. She transports food from the capital to the countryside and sells directly to farmers and herders. She then purchases raw goods from herders, and transports them to Ulaanbaater, Mongolia's capital city, for sale. 

Uurtsaih started her business in 2000 and has been successful. She works hard everyday to expand her business and hopes to provide a high-quality life to her two children. It is her dream that both become well-educated, good people. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug ($1,425) loan to buy supplies and storage space for her business.

loans.use: to buy supplies and storage space for her grocery business.

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is married and has two adult children. She sells women's  and men's shoes at Ulana Market in Pavlograd. She has been in this business for 13 years. When she started there was very little competition, but as more people entered this line of work, Galina's commitment to excellent customer service has allowed her small company to remain strong.

Galina has applied for a loan of 15,000 UAH to buy new inventory for the fall season. Galina hopes to earn additional income that she can spend meeting her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy additional inventory to sell to her customers

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie (or Naning, as she is know to friends and neighbors) lives in the village of Labni Mabuslo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Romulo, who makes a living farming vegetables. Both of them are doing their best to earn enough money to live well.  

Marjorie contributes to the family's income by running a sari-sari (or community-based) store. Her desire to expand this business has motivated her to apply for a loan for PHP 5,000.00.  She will use this loan to buy more groceries to sell to her customers. She hopes that she can count on your support to help make this possible.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ariana Group

texts.en:
This is Ariana group, made up of seven female members. Farzana is the group leader. All the group members hope that they will be successful and will be able to expand their businesses.

Farzana wants to take a loan for her husband who has a cart he uses for selling secondhand clothes. She has a share  in the business with him - she organizes the clothes and irons them, then her husband sells them in his cart.

Salma and Shakera also share a business with their husbands. They clean and package fresh fruit at home then their husbands sell the fruit in their carts.

Khorshed would like to take a loan for her brother’s gas-selling shop. He would like to buy the essential materials for his shop and expand his business.

Malaly wants to take a loan for her husband’s metal shop.

Taheba would like to take a loan for her husband’s dish-selling shop.

Shakila wants to take a loan for her husband’s gas-selling shop.

Together, they requested a group loan of 70,000 Afghani. They admire this effective loan process.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes for her husband to sell

loans.name: Zurgaanjin

texts.en: M. Zurgaanjin lives with his wife and daughter in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. His daughter is currently enrolled at the University of Science and Technology in Ulaanbatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife is unemployed. Zurgaanjin operates a transportation service in his town using a small transport truck. On average, he makes 10 daily trips helping to haul and deliver things for people. Zurgaanjin has found much success as a transport driver. He owns his truck and turns a daily average profit of 50,000 tugrugs. In the future, he has big plans to expand his business by buying new trucks and hiring more drivers. The success of his business is very important to him as he is paying to put his daughter through college. Zurgaanjin is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase spare parts for his truck.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his truck.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria I. is married with two children. She has a small grocery store. Maria has been in this business for 7 years. The store is located in her house, which makes it a true family business. The competition is low because there are only two grocery stores in the whole village. Maria's business goal is to open one more business location and increase her sales.

Maria would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to purchase more inventory. This will help her to serve more clients and receive additional income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria S. is 42 years old and married to Efren, who is engaged in the fish pond business.  They are thankful because they are blessed with four children: Thomas II, 21 years old; Ricky, 17 years old; Rose Ann, 15 years old and Efren Jr., 12 years old.  All of their children are studying.  

Gloria manages a general store business in the village of Marasat, Pequeño, San Mateo, Isabela. She aims to become successful in her business as her way of assisting her husband in providing for the needs of their family.  For this reason, she is doing everything to further expand her store. She is requesting  additional capital amounting to PHP11, 000 from KIVA lenders because she believes that through this, her income will also increase.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 28 year old Mercy M.  from Mbozi. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 1 and 5. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant because he is an orphan. Mercy has been running a shop  business since 1999. Her business is purchasing and selling various commodities in her shop. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Mercy currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to open the same business at a new location. In the future, she plans to improve quality and range of products. Mercy thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To open the same business at new location

loans.name: Enhtsetseg

texts.en:
Enhtsetseg L. is a widow with three daughters in ages ranging from 13 to 18. She currently lives in Arhangai province  with her three daughters and her younger brother. Enhtsetseg has a small retail business in various products including clothes and food products. She has been in the retail business since 2004 and her business has been her sole source of income to feed her family. She rents two stalls at the local market and retails cheap women and men's clothes imported from China as well as dairy products including cheese, milk, butter, and meat including mutton and beef. She mostly purchases these animal products from local herders at wholesale prices and retails them at the local market for profit. She keeps herself busy with selling two different kinds of products everyday and she says that she is working hard to support her family alone. 
Enhtsetseg requests a loan to purchase more clothes and dairy products for her retail business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and dairy products

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is a fish ball vendor. Using her motorcycle, she roams around her village in Raniag Ramon, Isabela, and other nearby villages to sell her merchandise. She is 28 years old, single and serves as the bread winner of the family. Her income of 200 PHP a day already is a big help to her parents and family.

At present, she is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP from KIVA lenders through its Field Partner Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. to improve her business. She needs to work hard to meet the needs of the family, especially those of her parents. She hopes that her business will be successful for the sake of their welfare.

loans.use: To improve her mobile fish ball business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase commodities in bulk for her store

loans.name: Uransaihan

texts.en:
Uransaihan G. is 44 years old, married and the father of four children ranging in age up to nineteen years old. His eldest daughter is a college student, the next two children are both in high school, while his youngest son is only a year old. The family currently lives in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces.

Uransaihan is a trained veterinarian and loves his job. Since 1996 he has been running a small veterinary pharmacy for domesticated animals, mostly for camels, horses, sheep, goats and cattle. He has been quite successful, as his pharmacy has increased its income from 200,000 MNT to 2,000,000 MNT (1,450 MNT = $1 USD) since its opening. Many local herders appreciate his business and are his loyal customers.

Uransaihan says that he would like a loan to expand his business by introducing up-to-date animal medicines for local herders. He would love one day to purchase his first family car. Buying a car has been his family's dream for the last decade. Uransaihan is resolved that this dream will come true one day.

loans.use: To buy up-to-date animal pharmaceuticals for his veterinary pharmacy

loans.name: Molortsetseg

texts.en:
Molortsetseg P. is 41 years old and the mother of three children. She currently resides with her husband and three children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her husband is a teacher in a local high school and her eldest daughter goes to a university in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her other two children are both high school students in Arhangai province.

Molortsetseg runs a small convenience store located in the town. She has been running this small convenience store for the last nine years and this business has been a major source of family income. She mostly sells food products including baked goods, soft-drinks, etc. Since starting the business in 2000, she has been doing pretty well and her business capital has expanded from 150,000 MNT to 400,000 MNT.

Molortsetseg says that her eldest daughter is in university and she would like to secure her tuition money with her business profit. She requests a loan to purchase more goods for her small business.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
“Work hard and endure hardships to attain success,” said Angelina A. of Barangay Ineangan, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is now a widow and a mother of three children. All of them were only high school graduates since she could not afford to send them to college. At the moment, her children are working hard in order to support their own families.

Angelina manages a food-vending business. With her dream to improve her business, she is now asking for a loan of 13,000 Philippine pesos. This amount is really of great help to make her business grow. She is also planning to save some of her income for her future needs and also to assist her children. She hopes that with her patience and sacrifices, her dreams will come into reality.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Buyantogtoh

texts.en:
Buyantogtoh B. lives in Uvurkhangai province, in the central part of Mongolia with her husband and one child. She started her business in 2000, driving her own car to the countryside and running a retail business. When she started her business, she actually had no car, but now due to her success and increased working capital, she has bought a car to expand her territory.

Buyantogtoh sells long-term preserved food products. By getting the loan she will be able to increase her working capital and purchase more products. This business is her family's main source of income. Her main goal for the future is to have her own business center. She is requesting 3,000,000 tugrugs (approx. $2076 USD) to purchase more candies and fruits to sell during the holidays.

loans.use: to purchase more candies and fruits to sell during the holidays

loans.name: Devidika

texts.en:
Devidika is a member of the Dodoma borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 38 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 20, 15, 13,  and 8 years old.

Davidika has owned a business selling local beer for 15 years, she works 13 hours  a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Davidika`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh  in order to buy more  maize for making local beer.

With the additional profits she gains from the use of this loan, Davidika hopes to save money, pay school fess and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for local beer

loans.name: Uranbileg

texts.en:
S. Uranbileg lives with her two children in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. Both of her children currently attend college, making it very difficult for the family to save money. Uranbileg operates a small food service business in her town. She makes and sells Mongolian traditional foods such as huushuur (meat covered with flour and fried from the outside) and buuz (steamed meat dumplings).

As these foods are popular for those on the go, her main customers are college students and office workers. She produces and packages her products quickly making it easy for customers to grab a quick bite to eat. For the future, her ultimate goal is to grow her business and open a small restaurant. She says, “It will be great contribution to my children's welfare.” She is requesting a 750,000 tugrug (~530 USD) loan to open that small restaurant.

loans.use: to open a small restaurant

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is a member of the Semtema borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 32 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 14, 12, 9 years old.

Rosemary started her own business selling tomatoes, potatoes and onions for 9 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 280,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Rosemary`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 300,000Tsh x in order to buy more tomatoes, potatoes and onions for sale.

With the additional profits she gains from the use of this loan, Rosemary hopes to save more money, pay school fess, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes, tomatoes, and onions

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a member of the Semtema A borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa,  she is 39 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 19, 15, 12, and 4 years old. She also cares for other 1 dependent.

Rukia has owned a stationary business for 3 years, she works 11 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Rukia`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more books, pen, pencil for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rukia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more stationary for sale

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Otgonbayar S. lives in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She currently operates a religious objects sales business from a counter at the local market in her town. She started her business in 2000 by renting a counter and has since worked very hard to grow and improve the business.

Otgonbayar has found success in her business and was recently able to purchase her own counter with her savings. Otgonbayar is always working hard to grow her business, however, providing for her family has always been her her primary concern. She uses all of her earnings to improve their quality of life.

For the future, Otgonbayar's dream is to establish a large trading center in her province. However, she knows in order to fulfill this dream she must first grow her business, increase her cash flow, and purchase new supplies. Otgonbayar is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to purchase more supplies for her religious objects business.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies for her religious objects business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: D. Narantuya lives with her two children in Uvurkhangai province, the central part of Mongolia. She runs a tea house and it is the main source of income for her family. Before opening the tea house, she prepared meals in her home and sold them, but now she is renting the tea house. Her future wish is to have her own service center with a hotel and a tea house. Narantuya is requesting 800,000 tugrugs (approx. $554 USD) to purchase food products to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: to purchase food products

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a member of the Dodoma west in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 41 year old woman, she is  married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 21, 19, 13, 9 years old.

Asha has owned a business selling firewood for 10 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 90,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Asha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more fire wood for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Asha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fire wood for sale

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn R.'s main source of income comes from providing automotive repair services in her community. She is 40 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the town of Katipunan. Jocelyn has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials for automotive repair services

loans.name: Enkhtuya

texts.en:
S. Enkhtuya is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Uvurkhangai province. She started her own business in 1996 by purchasing a Russian truck “ZIL -130”. Enkhtuya sells firewood and coal in the local market with her husband. For now, she is driving to the countryside to sell goods and in the winter she sells firewood and coal with the assistance of her husband. She is able to pay her daughter's student fees due to her successful business activities.

Enkhtuya is healthy and able to run her business further. Personally speaking, she is a good communicator and a meticulous person. Enkhtuya said: “I will keep running this business until my children get into a profession.” She is requesting 1,000,000 tugrugs (approx. $690 USD) to purchase repair parts for her truck for 200,000 tugrugs and firewood with the rest of 800,000 tugrugs.

loans.use: to purchase repair parts for her truck and firewood

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is a bread vendor. He is 25 years old and married to Mary Jane. They do not have a child yet but they are starting to save for their future children and to improving their standard of living. He purchases his products from a nearby bakeshop, then he uses his motorcycle to deliver bread inside and outside their village. His income from the business is really a big help in meeting daily needs at home.

Jonathan has applied for a loan of 4,000 PHP for additional business capital to purchase more bread that he can sell. He will also use some of the money for maintenance of his motorcycle for a safer ride. He is hoping that someday he can have his own bakeshop. He will do his best, work hard and learn to always be patient, he says.

loans.use: For additional business capital

loans.name: Maylene

texts.en:
Maylene is 24 years old and engaged in the direct selling of Avon and Natasha products. She sells beauty products, sandals, shoes, clothes, bags and other accessories. According to Maylene, her business is going well but she still wants to buy additional products to sell in her village to gain extra income for her daily needs. In line with this, she is now asking for financial capital of 4,000 PHP. She will use the loan to increase her merchandise, which she believes will also increase her income.

Maylene is still single and she is helping her parents. She hopes that she can access the loan she is requesting. She works hard to earn more profit for her family's welfare.

loans.use: Additional business capital

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is a frozen food vendor and a direct seller of Avon products in her village. She wants to improve the business she manages, and that is why she wants to borrow 4,000 PHP from Kiva lenders. She desires a bigger income and a more profitable business. Jean is proud that, with her business, she is able to help her husband meet the needs of their family.

Jean is happily married to Arnold and they have an 8-year-old daughter named Rejeina who is in elementary school. Jean hopes that she can continue to support her daughter’s education until college so she can have a better living someday. Jean wants the best for her family; thus, she is working very hard and patiently.

loans.use: Additional business capital

loans.name: Soronzonbold

texts.en:
Soronzonbold Banzrach is a 43-year-old man and lives with his wife and 18-year-old daughter. He currently lives with his family in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. This is Soronzonbold's second Kiva loan. He took his first Kiva loan to purchase spare parts for his truck. But he needed more funds to repair his truck engine and other parts. Thus he is requesting a greater loan. He is a XacBank (Kiva's partner Microfinance institution) repeat client.

Soronzonbold has been in the trucking business since 1998. He owns an old Russian truck that he uses for carrying freight between his city and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family is very supportive of his business and helps whenever he needs some help.

Soronzonbold says that he works hard to make sure that his daughter receives good education without any financial strain. Further, he dreams of exchanging his old truck for a new, powerful one.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his truck

loans.name: Teodosia

texts.en:
Teodosia C. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 60 years old. Teodosia is married and has two adult children.To make a living, Teodosia runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Teodosia has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 1,500 Philippine pesos (about $32) a month for these activities.

In 2006, Teodosia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teodosia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Teodosia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Teodosia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn G., 55 years old and from Tala, Caloocan City, believes that early training in classical music is a form of immunization and a mode to create healthy, secure individuals.

Evelyn (and her husband Angelito in photo) is a music enthusiast. Fifteen years ago, they started making engineered instruments, initially violins made of tropical wood which is bountiful in their forest-like village. They also offer repair services for run-down violins and other stringed instruments, restoring them to sound great again, just like a Stradivarius or a Guarnerius. Later, most of their violin clients asked for saxophones and other brass instruments. Evelyn says the net income from their violin shop now reaches at least P20,000 a month.

Evelyn says they have even gotten more clients since she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. From their profit, this husband and wife team has already put up a small store selling school supplies and looks forward to venturing into other businesses as well.

Evelyn now needs a new loan in the amount of P22,000 to purchase raw materials needed for the production of violins. She has dreaming of putting up a showroom for their crafts in a mall or any commercial center. Evelyn also wishes to see her only daughter finish college.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials needed in making violins

loans.name: Marciano

texts.en:
Marciano I. is from the village of Lower Tiparak, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. He is 33 years old. Marciano is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Marciano owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marciano has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Marciano joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marciano successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Marciano is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Marciano from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Amadine

texts.fr: S. Amandine est née en 1984 à Ahovo dans la commune d'Avrankou. Amadine est mariée et mère d’un seul enfant non encore scolarisé. Amadine est maîtresse coiffeuse. Avec les revenus de son activité, Amadine vient en aide à son mari. Pour l'accroissement de ses revenues, Amadine sollicite un crédit d’ALIDé pour améliorer ses prestations et répondre aux besoins en mèches et divers produits de coiffure de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Amadine S. was born in 1984 in Ahovo, in the commune of Avrankou. She's married and the mother of one child who does not attend school yet. Amadine is a hairdressing teacher. With the revenues of her business, she helps her husband. To increase her income, Amadine is seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé, in order to improve her services and meet customer demand for hair extensions and other haircare products.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and haircare products

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda is a member of the Dodoma west borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is single and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 16, 10, 5 years old.

Sauda has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 10 years, she works 7 hours  a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Sauda`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Sauda hopes to save  money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for sale

loans.name: Norberto

texts.en:
Norberto is a tricycle driver. He is 57 years old, married and has four children who are all married with their own families.

Norberto is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP from Kiva lenders through its Field Partner Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. This amount will be of great help in the maintenance of his motorcycle. Some of the things that he will buy are a replacement chain and sprocket so as to avoid an accident.

loans.use: To buy parts for his tricycle transport

loans.name: Yémagnissè

texts.fr: S. Yémagnissè est né 1984 à Ahovo. Yémagnissè est célibataire sans enfants et vit dans la commune d'Avrankou. Yémagnissè est un coiffeur. Yémagnissè a déjà 5 ans d’expérience dans ce métier. Face à l’importance de sa clientèle, Yémagnissè se trouve dans l'obligation d'agrandir son salon pour un meilleur accueil de ses clientes qui quelques fois sont obligés de rester sous des arbres au dehors. C’est pour cette raison que Yémagnissè sollicite un prêt d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
Yémagnissè S. was born in 1984 in Ahovo. He's single and without children, and lives in the Avrankou commune. Yémagnissè is a hairdresser, with five years of experience in this job. Facing a large clientele, he's forced to expand his salon to better welcome his customers, who sometimes have to stay under the trees outside. This is why Yémagnissè is seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand his hairdressing salon

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a member of the Dodoma borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 20 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child . Her child is 1 year old.

Mary has owned a food business selling vegetable for 2 years, she works 12 hours  a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 75,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Mary`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amoumt of 100,000 Tsh in order to cultivate more vegetable for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Mary hopes  to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To cultivate more vegetable

loans.name: Chak

texts.en: K. is a 23-year-old woman, residing in the best territory for tourists, in Siem Reap Province. K. would like to ask for a Kiva loan in order to buy a new motorcycle which she will use to make it easier commuting to her workplace. To earn a living, she works as an internal staff member for a massage place. She is married with two young children who are dependent on her income; her husband is an electrician.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina operates a general store in their village in Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. Aside from managing her store, Gina is also a dealer of cosmetics and apparel from AVON, Natasha, and MSE. She wants to expand her business thus, she is asking for a loan of PHP 23,000. She plans to buy more grocery items for her store and to purchase more products for her direct sales business.

She hopes to increase her business capital and her income; that’s why she is working with double effort. She is married to Melecio, a farmer, 43 years old, and they are blessed with two children. The loan she is requesting will help her family achieve a better standard of living someday.

loans.use: working capital for her store and direct sales businesses

loans.name: Redemtha

texts.en:
Redemtha is a member of the Malandege borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is 26 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 5 years old.

Redemtha has owned a clothing business selling kanga for 2 years, she works 8 hours  a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Redemtha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more kanga(fabric) for sale.

With the additional profits she gains from the use of this loan,Redemtha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale
